awd_titl_txt: The Immediacy, Inclusion and Productivity of NSF Grants Under the Broader Impact Criterion
awd_abstract_narration:
For the two decades, the National Science Foundation (NSF) has required scientists to discuss broader impacts (BIs) to show that their research extends beyond the laboratory. The BI criterion requires scientists to include BI activities, such as K-12 outreach and training graduate students, in their grant proposals. However, there are no standard frameworks for assessing BI activities. This project proposes a new framework for holistically assesses BIs, accounting for three factors: the immediacy of the BI activities, the inclusiveness of the BI activities, and the impact the BI activities have on scientific productivity. Immediacy refers to the active integration of broader impacts into the research design. Inclusiveness considers the impacts of the research on marginalized communities. Research productivity relates to the output of the research project. Reframing the evaluation of the BI criterion to highly immediacy, inclusiveness, and productivity will provide an opportunity to encourage inclusive research and support marginalized communities. This analysis is essential for ensuring that granting agencies meet their mission to support science that advances the whole nation's health, prosperity, and welfare. 

To analyze BIs, this project develops a new framework, called the Immediacy-Inclusion Criterion (IIC). The two dimensions of the IIC, immediacy and inclusion, form a 3X3 grid. There are three types of immediacy (intrinsic, direct, and extrinsic) and three types of inclusion (universal, advantaged, and inclusive) that characterize broader impact. This project has two central hypotheses: 1) the NSF funds more projects that helps advantaged groups compared to marginalized groups; and 2) funded projects with intrinsic immediacy are more productive than projects with extrinsic immediacy. The project tests these hypotheses by coding and analyzing NSF Project Report Outcomes, using the framework. This will provide insights on the most frequent Bis among NSF grants and how these vary by directorate, field, and type of institution. The work will also analyze the relationship between IIC and research outcomes, such as publication rates. This will provide insight on the relationship between the scientific output and broader impact. This work will inform not only the administration of NSF grants, but will provide wider insight on the relationship between scientific outputs and benefits to the wider public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the last 25 years, the National Science Foundation (NSF) has required principal investigators (PIs) to address the broader impacts of their research in order to secure funding. However, there has been a notable absence of comprehensive studies categorizing the types of proposed broader impacts, and the current methods for assessing broader impacts fail to account for two critical factors: immediacy and inclusion. Immediacy refers to the degree to which research integrates broader impacts into the project, while inclusion assesses the impacts on marginalized communities. Thus, it is imperative to evaluate the integration and inclusiveness of broader impacts in NSF-sponsored research.

This project aimed to introduce and employ the Inclusion-Immediacy Criterion (IIC) to gauge the immediacy and inclusion of NSF-sponsored research. Additionally, it sought to explore how various degrees of immediacy and inclusion correlate with scientific output.The central hypotheses were that the NSF funds more research that helps advantaged groups compare to marginalized communities, and projects with intrinsic immediacy are more productive than projects with extrinsic immediacy.


We have three main findings. First, we found that broader impacts that benefit advantage groups where 4 times more common than broader impacts that are inclusive of marginalized communities. Second, the most common broader impacts are training and education, and infrastructure for science. Third, when we compare the number and types of broader impacts proposed and the broader impacts accomplished, we find that researcher propose significantly more broader impacts than they achieve.

This research has important intellectual merit. First, this project develops a new framework, the IIC, that better assesses the immediacy and inclusion of science funding. By testing and developing the framework, the science policy community will be more informed about the impacts of science policies such as the BIC and responsible research and innovation (RRI). Second, the study pushes forward our understanding on a key problem in science policy, the relationship between R&D funding and productivity. The study will help determine the veracity of the belief that BIC makes scientists less productive.

This study also has several broader impacts. The results of this study will inform policy makers about R&D for marginalized communities and give them insight into creating grant award systems that encourage inclusive research. Second, the research team trained a diverse set of scholars from different fields, and under-represented minority groups. Creating a diverse science policy workforce expands the pool of ideas and will lead to improved policies. Finally, the PI disseminated the research to non-academic audiences through publication geared towards high students and teachers and he shared the findings with policy makers in the USA, Finland, and Sweden.
